pred:
**Youngest Person to Reach South Pole Solo: Scott Sears Completes 702-Mile Trek**

Scott Sears, a 27-year-old lieutenant in the First Battalion Royal Gurkha Rifles, has become the youngest person to reach the South Pole solo and unsupported. He completed his 702-mile trek on Christmas Day, more than 12 days ahead of schedule. Sears, brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray, spent five weeks navigating the Antarctic plateau, crevasse fields, and glaciers.

The journey was not without its challenges. Sears faced 150mph winds and temperatures of -50c, and at one point, he hit a wall with just 38km to go, feeling exhausted and unable to take another step. However, he persevered and continued on, fueled by juice, biltong, chocolate, and music on his iPod.

Sears' feat has raised over £33,500 for the Gurkha Welfare Trust to help rebuild schools in Gorkha, Nepal, which were destroyed in the 2015 earthquake. He also raised awareness for the trust through his social media updates and blog posts during his expedition.

Sears' achievement has been recognized by his family, including Andy Murray's mother, Judy, who tweeted congratulations to him. Sears himself said that it will take a few weeks for the experience to sink in, and he is looking forward to a shower and a meal after his grueling journey.

The Guinness Book of Records has yet to confirm whether Sears' feat will make it into the record books, but his achievement is undoubtedly an impressive one.assistant

Here is a rewritten version of the summary in a more concise and formal tone:

**Scott Sears Becomes Youngest Person to Reach South Pole Solo**

Lieutenant Scott Sears, a 27-year-old officer with the First Battalion Royal Gurkha Rifles, has successfully completed a 702-mile solo trek to the South Pole. He reached his destination on Christmas Day, more than 12 days ahead of schedule.

Sears faced extreme weather conditions, including 150mph winds and temperatures of -50c, and overcame a personal crisis when he hit a wall with just 38km to go. Despite these challenges, he persevered and completed his journey.

Sears' achievement has raised over £33,500 for the Gurkha Welfare Trust to rebuild schools in Gorkha, Nepal, which were destroyed in the 2015 earthquake. His feat has also been recognized by his family, including Andy Murray's mother,
answers: While many people were unwrapping gifts on Christmas Day, the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray was wrapping up a 700-mile, 38-day journey through brutally cold temps and blistering winds—and, he hopes, setting a world record. Scott Sears, 27, reached the South Pole on Monday, and he says he's the youngest person ever to do so solo, though Guinness has yet to offer its final seal of approval, the BBC notes. "MERRY CHRISTMAS FROM THE SOUTH POLE! Absolutely chuffed to pieces," he wrote on his blog, where he documented his unassisted adventure, which included temperatures of minus 58 degrees and wind gusts of up to 150mph. Sears said he was so tired when he finally took a rest after his trek that he fell asleep "within about 2 minutes of my head hitting the mat." Sears, whose sister, Kim, is married to the tennis star, describes a grueling expedition with icy, crevasse-marred terrain and an isolation made worse when the "iPod poltergeist" would occasionally strike, causing his music player to stop working. He says he "truly hit a wall" on Christmas Eve, where "everything was just saying 'no more, not one more step.'" But he devoured some dried meat, juice, and chocolate and pushed through, even hanging up his stinky socks as "makeshift stockings" for Santa that night. Sears' message from Andy Murray's mom once he arrived at his destination: "Well done Scott Sears." If Guinness confirms Sears' feat, he'll be three years younger than the previous record-holder, per the Telegraph. (Prince Harry drank champagne out of a prosthetic leg when he arrived at the South Pole.)

pred:
A convicted murderer, Michael David Elliot, 40, who was serving five life sentences for four murders and an armed robbery, escaped from the Ionia Correctional Facility in Michigan on Sunday evening. Elliot, who was convicted in 1993, was last seen wearing a blue and orange state prison uniform, but was later spotted wearing black pants, a white t-shirt, white tennis shoes, and a white beanie cap.

After escaping, Elliot carjacked a woman using a box cutter and held her hostage during a 100-mile drive to Elkhart County. The woman escaped at a gas station and Elliot fled in her red Jeep Liberty. The car was found abandoned in Shipshewana, Indiana, and a woman living in the neighborhood reported seeing the car around 5:30 a.m. on Monday.

Indiana State Police launched a manhunt for Elliot, who was described as a 5'8", 165-pound white male with brown hair and eyes. He was last seen wearing black pants, a white t-shirt, white tennis shoes, and a white beanie cap. Police searched the community, including Westview Schools, which were placed on lockdown, but were unable to find Elliot.

On Monday evening, Elliot was arrested in LaPorte County, Indiana, after a short chase. He was found in a stolen vehicle and was taken into custody without incident. Elliot is being held without bond on felony car theft and resisting charges.

The Michigan Department of Corrections Director, Dan Heyns, said that Elliot was not assigned to the kitchen, but was able to get a white kitchen uniform, which may have helped him evade security cameras and fencing. An investigation into the escape is ongoing, and authorities are reviewing the incident to determine how Elliot was able to escape.

Elliot's family has been notified, and police are urging anyone who comes into contact with him to contact law enforcement immediately. He is considered armed and dangerous.assistant

answers: A convicted killer who escaped from a Michigan prison yesterday and carjacked a woman has been arrested after a car chase in rural LaPorte Country, Indiana, WNDU reports. Michael David Elliot, 40, allegedly stole a woman's red jeep and abandoned it in the small town of Shipshewana, Indiana, this afternoon. A woman spotted the car and called police, who said the vehicle had been seen in the area as early as 5:30am. Then a call about a stolen vehicle came in to the LaPorte County Sheriff's Office, and a deputy saw the vehicle and attempted a traffic stop, WOOD-TV reports. But the driver kept going and led authorities on a 5-minute chase. Stop sticks disabled his tires in Kankakee Township; Elliot jumped out and tried to run but was arrested and booked. He was serving five life sentences for the murders of four people when he broke out of the Ionia Correctional Facility yesterday by slipping through a gap in the fencing system.

pred:
**Dramatic Pursuit of Stolen Tractor Ends in Downtown Denver**

A stolen tractor towing an attachment was pursued by Denver Police Department vehicles through central Denver on Friday night, resulting in a dramatic chase that ended in Lower Downtown (LoDo). The tractor, stolen from a Denver Water facility, was driven through busy city streets and sidewalks, causing damage to several cars and buildings.

The pursuit began near City Park and ended near 15th and Market Streets in LoDo, where a police cruiser rammed the tractor head-on, causing its airbags to deploy. The officer driving the cruiser then used a Taser to subdue the tractor driver. Two police officers were taken to the hospital with injuries, but were treated and released by Saturday morning.

Witnesses described the pursuit as intense, with the tractor swerving through streets and sidewalks, and the police cruiser's impact causing a significant stop to the chase. The suspect, a male, was apprehended and taken to an ambulance.

The Denver Police Department has not released the suspect's identity, as the investigation is ongoing. No shots were fired during the pursuit. The incident is still under investigation, and authorities are working to determine the circumstances surrounding the stolen tractor and the pursuit.

The dramatic chase was captured on video, showing the tractor and police vehicles navigating through downtown Denver. The incident serves as a reminder of the risks and challenges faced by law enforcement officers in their daily duties.assistant

answers: Imagine looking outside and seeing over a dozen cop cars chasing ... a tractor. That was the scene in Denver last night when a stolen tractor towing an attachment smashed into cars and buildings as it plowed through downtown, the Huffington Post reports. A Palestinian teenager, Muhammad Hussein Abu Khdeir, 16, was abducted and killed in Jerusalem, sparking widespread outrage and violence. The incident occurred just hours after the funeral of three Jewish Israeli teenagers who were kidnapped and killed, allegedly by Hamas militants. The Israeli government has condemned the killing and launched an investigation, while Palestinian leaders have accused Jewish extremists of carrying out the revenge attack.

The incident has escalated tensions between Israelis and Palestinians, with both sides trading blame and accusations. The Israeli government has reinforced its border with Gaza and launched air strikes against Palestinian militant targets, while Palestinian militants have responded with rocket fire into southern Israel.

The funeral of Muhammad Abu Khdeir was delayed due to a post-mortem examination, which is still ongoing. His family has accused the Israeli authorities of holding up the investigation and has called for the perpetrators to be brought to justice.

The killing has also sparked widespread condemnation from around the world, with many calling for an end to the violence and a return to peace talks. The United States has urged restraint and called for an investigation into the incident.

In related news, the Israeli government has arrested over 400 West Bank activists, most of whom are affiliated with Hamas, in response to the kidnapping and killing of the three Israeli teenagers. Palestinian leaders have accused Israel of using the incident as a pretext to crack down on Palestinian activists and undermine the newly formed unity government.

The incident has also highlighted the deep-seated divisions and mistrust between Israelis and Palestinians, with many on both sides calling for an end to the violence and a return to peace talks. The killing of Muhammad Abu Khdeir has sparked widespread outrage and grief, and has raised concerns about the future of the Israeli-Palestinian peace process.assistant

They called his cell phone but "my son wasn't answering," his mother adds, per the BBC. An hour later, the Palestinian teen was found dead in an apparent revenge killing, so burned beyond recognition that DNA samples were needed to confirm his identify, father Hussein Abu Khudair tells NBC News, adding, per Time, "The settlers killed my son, they kidnapped him and killed him." In response to mortar and rocket attacks from Gaza, "the Israeli Air Force attacked 15 terror sites in Gaza early Thursday," an Israel Defense Forces official notes. pred:
**In Other Words Bookstore Cuts Ties with Portlandia**

The In Other Words bookstore in Portland, Oregon, has announced that it will no longer allow the TV show Portlandia to film at its location. The decision comes after a series of incidents, including a recent filming that left the store a mess and staff mistreated, as well as the show's perceived negative impact on the neighborhood and the city.

The bookstore's community had previously agreed to discontinue its relationship with Portlandia due to the show's trans-antagonistic and trans-misogynist content, as well as its lack of representation of people of color. The show's portrayal of feminist bookstore owners Toni and Candace, played by Carrie Brownstein and Fred Armisen, was seen as problematic and offensive.

The bookstore's management also criticized the show's handling of filming, which resulted in lost business for the store and its neighbors. The show's payment to the bookstore was deemed insufficient to cover the costs of filming, and the additional exposure from the show did not provide financial or political support.

The decision to cut ties with Portlandia was made by the current board, staff, and volunteers, who stand behind the collective decision. The bookstore is now seeking donations to continue serving as a hub for Portland's social justice community.

The controversy surrounding Portlandia's filming at In Other Words has sparked a wider conversation about gentrification, racism, and white supremacy in Portland. The show's portrayal of the city and its communities has been criticized for being out of touch and insensitive, and its use of humor has been accused of being lazy and harmful.

In response to the controversy, the bookstore has placed a sign in its window reading "Fuck Portlandia" and is encouraging supporters to donate and volunteer. The sign has become a symbol of the bookstore's commitment to social justice and its refusal to compromise its values for the sake of popularity.assistant

answers: Portland's In Other Words bookstore is well known to Portlandia fans as the fictional Women and Women First bookstore featured in sketches on the show—but it's safe to say ties have been severed between the bookstore and the show, considering a sign that appears on the bookstore's door reading, "Fuck Portlandia! Transmisogyny – Racism – Gentrification – Queer Antagonism – Devaluation of Feminist Discourse." The Willamette Week tried on Tuesday to get an explanation from the bookstore, and a representative at first offered an interview, but also asked (repeatedly) for the Week to post a link to an online fundraiser the bookstore is running. After the Week declined to guarantee a link would be posted (though one did, in fact, end up getting posted in the ensuing article), the bookstore took back its offer of an interview in no uncertain terms. "After some consideration and research we've decided to officially tell the Willamette Weekly to go fuck themselves," read a message from the rep. "Your paper has absolutely zero journalistic professionalism and you are scummy rape apologists. Thanks for the opportunity tho! Have a great night." Then, Wednesday, a blog post went up on the bookstore's website explaining the "Fuck Portlandia" sign. It was placed on the window, and the store's relationship with the show was formally discontinued, as "a direct response to a particular egregious filming of the show in our space which saw our store left a mess, our staff mistreated, our neighbors forced to close and lose business for a day without warning, and our repeated attempts to obtain accountability or resolution dismissed," the blog post reads. "It was also a direct response to a show which is in every way diametrically opposed to our politics and the vision of society we’re organizing to realize. A show which has had a net negative effect on our neighborhood and the city of Portland as a whole." There's a lot more where that came from, here.

pred:
The California State Auditor's Office has released a report highlighting several instances of improper governmental activities and employee misconduct across various state agencies. The report includes seven examples of investigations that substantiated improper governmental activities, including misuse of state time, inaccurate attendance records, economically wasteful activities, and misuse of government property.

The report found that four employees at several agencies misused state time, resulting in a loss of approximately $160,000. Two employees at California State University, Fresno, engaged in egregious time and attendance abuse, failing to account for over 5,100 hours of work and costing the state over $111,000. A California Department of Motor Vehicles employee slept at her desk for over 2,200 hours, costing the state over $40,000.

The report also highlighted instances of nepotism, bad-faith hires, improper promotions, and other misconduct by executive management within two state entities. Additionally, a California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation employee misused state time by regularly leaving work early, resulting in a loss of nearly $9,000.

The report also found that a California Correctional Health Care Services director of nursing reassigned a licensed vocational nurse to a position for which she was overqualified, resulting in a loss of nearly $30,000. A California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection assistant chief misused state resources by building an unauthorized structure on state property.

The report was released alongside an audit that found a California DMV data operator slept three hours a day at her desk for three years, despite complaints from colleagues. The employee continues to work for the state, and the DMV failed to take disciplinary action. The report also found that a high-ranking Cal Fire chief had an unauthorized structure built on state-owned property during work hours.

The California State Auditor's Office investigated 1,481 instances of alleged improper governmental activities in the past year, and the report highlights the need for improved oversight and accountability within state agencies.assistant

pred:
Egypt is facing its worst crisis since President Mohamed Mursi took office six months ago. The crisis began when Mursi issued a decree giving himself wide powers and shielding his decisions from judicial review. The opposition, led by the National Salvation Front, has been protesting against the decree and the draft constitution written by an Islamist-dominated assembly.

On Wednesday, Islamist supporters of Mursi clashed with opposition protesters outside the presidential palace, with both sides throwing stones and petrol bombs. Riot police tried to separate the two groups, but failed to halt the fighting. Medical sources reported that 211 people were wounded, some with gunshot wounds.

The opposition has accused Mursi of creating a new autocracy and has called for him to retract the decree and defer the referendum on the constitution. Mursi has shown no sign of buckling under pressure, and has instead called for calm and dialogue.

The United States has weighed in on the crisis, with Secretary of State Hillary Clinton calling for dialogue and respect for the rights of all citizens. British Foreign Secretary William Hague has also called for restraint on all sides and urged dialogue.

The crisis has spread to other cities, with offices of the Muslim Brotherhood's political party in Ismailia and Suez being torched. The opposition has also called for a national dialogue, but Mursi has shown no sign of willingness to compromise.

The army, which has traditionally been the muscle behind Egyptian presidents, has gone back to barracks and is not intervening in the crisis. State institutions, with the partial exception of the judiciary, have mostly fallen in behind Mursi.

The crisis has raised concerns about the stability of Egypt, which has a peace deal with Israel and receives $1.3 billion in military aid from the United States each year. The opposition has called for Mursi to be overthrown and the "downfall of the regime," but Mursi has shown no sign of willingness to step down.

The crisis is likely to continue in the coming days, with both sides dug in and refusing to compromise. The outcome is uncertain, but one thing is clear: Egypt is facing a major crisis that could have far-reaching consequences for the country and the region.assistant

answers: Egyptian President Mohamed Morsi returned to the presidential palace today after fleeing yesterday when it was thronged by protesters, Reuters reports. Though 200 demonstrators camped out overnight, traffic was back to normal today and riot police had left the area. In yesterday's clashes, 35 protesters and 40 police officers were hurt. And things are looking to heat up again soon: The Muslim Brotherhood has called for a protest at the palace today against the "oppressive abuses" of the opposition, and the opposition in response called for leftist demonstrators to head back to the palace, leading to fears of violent clashes. Opposition protesters want Morsi to retract his expanded powers and stop a Dec. 15 vote on the new constitution hastily drafted by Islamists. Though they called yesterday's protest a "last warning" to the president, Reuters notes that they have little real chance of stopping the vote, which Morsi is confident will approve the constitution.

pred:
**Jamaican Bobsled Team Makes Catchy Comeback at Sochi Winter Olympics**

The Jamaican bobsled team is making a triumphant return to the Winter Olympics after a 12-year absence. The team, piloted by Winston Watts, will compete in the men's two-man bobsled event on February 16. To get fans pumped up, the Jamaican Tourist Board has released a catchy reggae tune called "The Bobsled Song," which syncs perfectly with the Olympic bobsled track's twists and turns.

The song, written by Sidney Mills and Jon Notar, features a bright 8-bit music video that tracks the team's progress on a map of the Sochi bobsled course. Fans can download the song and play it at the exact moment the Jamaican bobsled team begins their run, creating an amazing theme song that reflects the team's progress throughout the race.

The Jamaican team qualified for the two-man bobsled competition for the first time since 2002, making it without racing in any World Cup events but accumulating enough points in lower-tier races in North America. While considered a long shot to win a medal, the team's participation is a significant milestone for Jamaican sports.

The Jamaican bobsled team's return to the Winter Olympics is reminiscent of their historic debut in the 1988 Calgary Games, which was depicted in the film "Cool Runnings." Fans can follow the team's progress on Twitter @JAMBOBSLED and watch their training sessions, including a recent training session on February 15.

Get ready to cheer on the Jamaican bobsled team with "The Bobsled Song" and follow their journey to the Sochi Winter Olympics.assistant
